docs.title: Commands
docs.text: Are listed on this page commands used/implemented by poetry-pyinstaller-plugin and solely exposed through Poetry CLI.

docs.title: poetry build
docs.text:
Legacy build command provided by Poetry, PyInstaller targets are always build when format is unspecified.

Example

poetry build
Expected output (linux)
Building pyinstaller [python3.12 manylinux_2_39_x86_64]
  - Building my-tool
  - Built my-tool
Building package_name (0.1.0)
Building sdist
  - Building sdist
  - Built package_name-0.1.0.tar.gz
Building wheel
  - Building wheel
  - Built package_name-0.1.0-py3-none-any.whl

Distributing bundled binaries in Wheels ?

Inclusion of executables in Wheel archives is only supported by this command.

docs.title: poetry pyinstaller build
docs.text:
Build PyInstaller targets only.

Example

poetry pyinstaller build
Expected output (linux)
Building pyinstaller [python3.12 manylinux_2_39_x86_64]
  - Building my-tool
  - Built my-tool

docs.title: poetry pyinstaller show
docs.text:
Show installed version of poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.

Example

poetry pyinstaller show
Expected output (linux)
poetry-pyinstaller-plugin x.x.x

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
You can debug your PyInstaller builds by changing the logging level using legacy Poetry's -v, --verbose CLI option.

Available logging levels:

  • -v: Set --log-level=WARN
  • -vv: Set --log-level=INFO
  • -vvv: Set --log-level=DEBUG AND --debug=all

Warning

--debug=all option of PyInstaller enable debug logging in final executable.

docs.title: Build folder & Specs
docs.text:
Intermediate files created by PyInstaller during build are kept within your project under build/<platform>/<target> directory.

PyInstaller's .spec files are by default saved in dist/pyinstaller/<platform>/.specs directory.

Info

Build folders are not re-used between builds to ensure repeatability of builds with clean & accurate dependency tree.

docs.title: Project setup
docs.text:
Given this very simple project structure: 

.
├── src
│   └── package_name
│         └── main.py
├── pyproject.toml
└── README.md

pyproject.toml
[project]
name = "package_name"
version = "0.1.0"
description = ""
readme = "README.md"
requires-python = ">=3.12,<3.15"

[tool.poetry.dependencies]
python = "^3.10"

[tool.poetry.requires-plugins]
poetry-pyinstaller-plugin = { version = ">=2.0.0,<3.0.0" }

[build-system]
requires = ["poetry-core>=2.0.0,<3.0.0"]
build-backend = "poetry.core.masonry.api"

[dependency-groups]
dev = [
    "pyinstaller (>=6.16.0,<7.0.0)"
]
main.py
if __name__ == '__main__':
    print("Hello World !")

docs.title: Add target for pyinstaller
docs.text:
To add a new target, include following block to your pyproject.yaml:

[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.targets]
my-tool = "package_name/main.py"

docs.title: Build your target
docs.text:
To build your target, run the following command: 

poetry build
Expected output (linux)
Building pyinstaller [python3.12 manylinux_2_39_x86_64]
  - Building my-tool
  - Built my-tool
Building package_name (0.1.0)
Building sdist
  - Building sdist
  - Built package_name-0.1.0.tar.gz
Building wheel
  - Building wheel
  - Built package_name-0.1.0-py3-none-any.whl

docs.title: Test your target
docs.text:
Build assets are stored within dist/pyinstaller directory under a platform specific directory. Output directory might defer from this example.

Run from your project directory: 

./dist/pyinstaller/<platform>/my-tool/my-tool
Expected output (linux)
Hello World !

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Poetry PyInstaller Plugin is a lightweight extension for Poetry that makes packaging Python applications into standalone executables effortless.

It bridges the gap between Poetry’s dependency management and PyInstaller binary packaging, letting you build distributable apps directly from your Poetry project without leaving the familiar poetry workflow.

With a single command, you can bundle your Python project (including all dependencies and metadata) into a platform-native executable, perfect for distribution to users without Python installed.

Project Links

  • PyPI Project: pypi.org - poetry-pyinstaller-plugin
  • Source Code: github.com - thmahe/poetry-pyinstaller-plugin
  • Issue Tracker: github.com - thmahe/poetry-pyinstaller-plugin/issues
  • Documentation: poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.tmahe.fr

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Poetry 2.xOlder releases

To install poetry-pyinstaller-plugin add the following section to your pyproject.toml

pyproject.toml
[tool.poetry.requires-plugins]
poetry-pyinstaller-plugin = { version = ">=2.0.0,<3.0.0", extras = ["plugin"] }

To complete the installation: 

poetry add --group dev pyinstaller
poetry install
Well done, your project is ready for pyinstaller builds !

Depending on installation method, use one of the following command:

Installed with pip or debian package

poetry self add poetry-pyinstaller-plugin
Or

Installed with pipx
pipx inject poetry poetry-pyinstaller-plugin

To complete the installation: 

poetry add --group dev pyinstaller
poetry install
Well done, your project is ready for pyinstaller builds !

Info

If you are having troubles installing the plugin please refer to Poetry documentation - Using Plugins

docs.title: Check plugin version
docs.text:
To check plugin installation you can run the following command:

Shell
$ poetry pyinstaller show
poetry-pyinstaller-plugin x.x.x

docs.title: Hooks
docs.text:
Hooks allow you to call a python function before and/or after the PyInstaller build.

Each hook is passed a hook object that allows access to Poetry, pyproject.toml data, logging methods and the virtual environment.

This lets you have further control in niche situations.

Warning

Hooks cannot be called from externaly managed package ! Ensure to have your hook module aside of one of the package managed by your Poetry project.

For more information: Poetry Documentation - The pyproject.toml file - packages

docs.title: Attributes
docs.text: Name Type Description type Literal["pre", "post"] Type of hook once registered by Poetry name str Hook's name as referenced in pyproject.toml poetry poetry.poetry.Poetry Poetry instance of current build pyproject_data TOMLDocument Parsed pyproject.toml, similar to a Dictionary platform str Name of the current platform

docs.title: Private Attributes
docs.text:
Name Type Description _venv Env poetry.utils.env VirtualEnv instance _io IO cleo.io.io IO instance

Warning

Before using private attributes please check available below methods.

If something is missing, don't hesitate to raise your hand and log a new feature request !

docs.title: PluginHook.run(command: str, *args: str) -> str
docs.text:
Run command in current Poetry environment, returns output of command.

Argument Type Description command str Command to run *args str Arguments for command Example
from poetry_pyinstaller_plugin import PluginHook


def my_hook(hook: PluginHook):
    hook.run("echo", "Hello world !")

docs.title: PluginHook.run_pip(*args: str) -> str
docs.text:
Run pip in current Poetry environment, returns output of command.

Argument Type Description *args str Arguments for pip Example
from poetry_pyinstaller_plugin import PluginHook


def my_hook(hook: PluginHook):
    hook.run_pip("install", "requests")

docs.title: PluginHook.is_debug() -> bool
docs.text:
Returns True if current IO is running with debug enabled.

Example
from poetry_pyinstaller_plugin import PluginHook


def my_hook(hook: PluginHook):
    if hook.is_debug():
        hook.run_pip("install", "debug-package")

docs.title: PluginHook.log(msg: str) -> None
docs.text:
Logs a message to current Poetry IO, displayed during poetry build execution.

Example
from poetry_pyinstaller_plugin import PluginHook


def my_hook(hook: PluginHook):
    hook.log("Hello world !")

docs.title: PluginHook.warning(msg: str) -> None
docs.text:
Logs warning message to current Poetry IO, displayed during poetry build execution.

Message is displayed in bold yellow

Example
from poetry_pyinstaller_plugin import PluginHook


def my_hook(hook: PluginHook):
    hook.warning("Warning: unable to...")

docs.title: PluginHook.error(msg: str) -> None
docs.text:
Logs error message to current Poetry IO, displayed during poetry build execution.

Message is displayed in bold red

Example
from poetry_pyinstaller_plugin import PluginHook


def my_hook(hook: PluginHook):
    hook.error("Fatal error: unable to...")

docs.title: PluginHook.debug(msg: str) -> None
docs.text:
Logs debug message to current Poetry IO, displayed during poetry build execution.

Message is only displayed when debug mode is enabled

Example
from poetry_pyinstaller_plugin import PluginHook


def my_hook(hook: PluginHook):
    hook.debug("Initializing hook...")

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Start by registering your hooks as follows:

pyproject.toml
[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin]
# ran after requirements install and before builds
pre-build = "hooks.pyinstaller:post_build"

# ran after all builds are done
post-build = "hooks.pyinstaller:post_build"

Basic hooks example:

hooks/pyinstaller.py
from poetry_pyinstaller_plugin import PluginHook


def pre_build(hook: PluginHook):
    hook.log("Hello from pre-hook !")
    hook.warning("Oup ! Something went wrong, but it's OK !")
    hook.run("echo", "Hello world !")


def post_build(hook: PluginHook):
    hook.log("Hello from post-hook !")
    hook.debug("Debug message")

Test your hooks by either running poetry build or poetry pyinstaller build:

Expected OutputWith Debug Enabled -vvv 
Running pre-build hook 'hooks.pyinstaller:pre_build'
Hello from pre-hook !
Oup ! Something went wrong, but it's OK !
Building pyinstaller [python3.12 manylinux_2_39_x86_64]
  - Building my-tool
Running post-build hook 'hooks.pyinstaller:post_build'
Hello from post-hook !

Running pre-build hook 'hooks.pyinstaller:pre_build'
Hello from pre-hook !
Oup ! Something went wrong, but it's OK !
Running 'echo Hello world !'
++ Hello world !
++ 
Building pyinstaller [python3.12 manylinux_2_39_x86_64]
...
...
Running post-build hook 'hooks.pyinstaller:post_build'
Hello from post-hook !
Debug message

docs.title: Plugin Configuration
docs.text:
Plugin options are declared in [tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin] section of your pyproject.toml file.

Since release 2.x of poetry-pyinstaller-plugin all PyInstaller options are configurable at target or plugin level.

Order of precedence for options: target -> plugin -> default

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Are listed in this section, options that are only configurable at plugin level.

docs.title: tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.pre-build
docs.text:
Allow you to call a python function before the pyinstaller build.

Example
[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin]
pre-build = "hooks.pyinstaller:post_build"

For more information about Hooks you can read Reference > Hooks.

docs.title: tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.post-build
docs.text:
Allow you to call a python function after the pyinstaller build.

Example
[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin]
post-build = "hooks.pyinstaller:post_build"

For more information about Hooks you can read Reference > Hooks.

docs.title: Target Options
docs.text:
As mentioned at the beginning of this page, all target options can be defined globally at plugin level and get effective to all targets (if not overridden at target level).

Following given order of precedence: target -> plugin -> default

Option precedence example
[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin]
# Override default "onedir" build type for all targets
type = "onefile" 

[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.targets.my-tool]
source = "entrypoint.py"
# Override global option 'tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.type'
type = "onedir"

[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.targets.my-tool-2]
source = "entrypoint.py"

# my-tool ---> "onedir" build as set in target config
# my-tool-2 -> "onefile" build as set in plugin config

docs.title: Target Configuration
docs.text:
Target options are specified in [tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.targets.<TARGET>] section of pyproject.toml file. Where <TARGET> is the final executable name produced by PyInstaller.

Since release 2.x of poetry-pyinstaller-plugin all PyInstaller options are configurable at target or plugin level.

Order of precedence for options: target -> plugin -> default

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Are listed in this section, supported options allowing you to customize target build.

docs.title: source path required
docs.text:
Path to your future executable entrypoint.

Example - Minified form
[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.targets]
my-tool = "my_package/entrypoint.py"
# or
my-tool = { source = "my_package/entrypoint.py" }

Or

Example - Dedicated target block
[tool.poetry-pyinstaller-plugin.targets.my-tool]
source = "my_package/entrypoint.py"

Above examples produces identical target specs, using dedicated target block is heavily recommended to keep your pyproject.toml readable.

docs.title: type str
docs.text:
Default: onedir

Type of PyInstaller distribution format.

  • onedir: Create a one-folder bundle containing an executable
  • onefile: Create a one-file bundled executable

docs.title: bundle boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Bundle executable to Wheels and register them as executable scripts.

docs.title: no-upx boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Disable UPX archiving.

docs.title: strip boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Apply a symbol-table strip to the executable and shared libraries Not recommended for Windows

docs.title: console boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Open a console window for standard IO (default). This option has no effect in Windows if the first script is a .pyw file.

docs.title: windowed boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Windows and Mac OS X: do not provide a console window for standard IO. On macOS this also triggers building a macOS .app bundle. On Windows this option is automatically set if the first script is a .pyw file.

This option is ignored on *NIX systems.

docs.title: icon path
docs.text:
Default: PyInstaller’s icon

Set the icon for executables.

  • FILE.ico - Apply the icon to a Windows executable.
  • FILE.exe,ID - Extract the icon with ID from an exe.
  • FILE.icns - Apply the icon to the .app bundle on macOS.

Use NONE to not apply any icon, thereby making the OS to show system default.

docs.title: uac-admin boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Using this option creates a Manifest that will request elevation upon application start.

docs.title: uac-uiaccess boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Using this option allows an elevated application to work with Remote Desktop.

docs.title: argv-emulation boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Enable argv emulation for macOS app bundles.

If enabled, the initial open document/URL event is processed by the bootloader and the passed file paths or URLs are appended to sys.argv.

docs.title: arch str macOS only
docs.text:
Default: null

Target architecture. Accepted values: x86_64, arm64, universal2.

docs.title: hidden-import str | list[str]
docs.text:
Default: null

Hidden imports needed by the executable.

docs.title: runtime-hooks list
docs.text:
Default: null

One or more runtime hook paths to bundle with the executable.

These hooks are executed before any other code or module to set up special features of the runtime environment.

docs.title: add-version bool
docs.text:
Default: false

Suffix executable names with current package version. Dynamic versioning over poetry-dynamic-versioning plugin is supported.

These hooks are executed before any other code or module to set up special features of the runtime environment.

docs.title: when str
docs.text:
Default: null - targets are always built.

Restrict build depending on package version. Possible values:

  • release
  • prerelease

docs.title: certifi.append list[str]
docs.text:
Default: []

List of certificates to include in certifi.where()

Warning

certifi package must be registered in project dependencies if enabled.

docs.title: collect dict[str, list[str]]
docs.text:
Default: null

Define which data from specific package or module must be included in final archive.

Supported keys:

  • submodules: Collect all submodules for specified package(s) or module(s)
  • data: Collect all data for specified package(s) or module(s)
  • binaries: Collect all binaries for specified package(s) or module(s)
  • all: Collect all submodules, data files, and binaries for specified package(s) or module(s)

docs.title: copy-metadata list[str]
docs.text:
Default: []

List of packages for which metadata must be copied.

docs.title: include dict[Path, Path]
docs.text:
Default: []

Data file(s) to include. {source: destination}

docs.title: package dict[Path, Path]
docs.text:
Default: []

File(s) to include with executable. {source: destination}

docs.title: exclude-poetry-include boolean
docs.text:
Default: false

Disable [tool.poetry.include] and use plugin/target settings instead.
